availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p: At the May Term 1861 -- a Judgment for $60 was rendered in favor of the Commonwealth against J W Clark for keeping a Tipling House by the Equity and Criminal court of Fulton county the facts were these. Clark was a regularly licensed Tavern Keeper -- and kept his bar in a different house from his tavern house, this he was advised he had a right to do under the revised statutes by the Commonwealths attorney of the first Judicial district and for thus keeping his bar he was Indicted and fined Clark is a good law abiding citizen and kept a Tavern & Bar in good faith a Petition Setting forth these facts was gotten up -- Signed by all the officials of Fulton County and many of her citizens and was placed in my possession to be presented to the Governor asking a remission of said fine which Petition I have lost on my way to Frankfort

Fulton Eq. Ct
$60. } Tipling
J W Clark
